results.headline: Silence Goes Beyond Golden; It Could Save Two Lives

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Thousand Words

results.summary_short: In “A Thousand Words,” Eddie Murphy plays a literary agent who is magically connected to the fate of a tree.

results.headline: Couple’s Mutual Attraction and Mutual Disaster

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Apart

results.summary_short: In “Apart,” a young man has just emerged from a two-year coma with no memory of the trauma that preceded it, and a young woman is using casual sex to forget the same event.

results.headline: Blackmail, Big Money and Gross-Outs Galore
results.display_title: Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie

results.summary_short: Tim Heidecker and Eric Wareheim are in theaters, in a movie about paying back a billion dollars. Will Ferrell helps out.

results.headline: A Boy Pays for Mother’s Mistakes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Snowtown Murders

results.summary_short: “The Snowtown Murders” is based on the 1990s exploits of the notorious serial killer John Bunting and his crew in Adelaide, Australia.

results.headline: Longing for the Beauty That Is Rome in the Form of Earthly Goddesses

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Salt of Life

results.summary_short: “The Salt of Life” is an Italian comedy starring, Gianni Di Gregorio as an aging man dazzled and a little depressed by the abundance of beautiful young women who do not notice him.

results.headline: A Teenage ‘Home Alone’ Gone Wild

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Project X

results.summary_short: Thomas Mann plays a high-school nobody who goes down in history after an extreme party in “Project X,” directed by Nima Nourizadeh.

results.headline: Tracing the Great Recession to a Memo 40 Years Ago
results.display_title: Heist: Who Stole the American Dream?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Heist: Who Stole the American Dream?

results.summary_short: The documentary “Heist: Who Stole the American Dream?” argues that the seeds of the recent financial collapse were sown 40 years ago in a memo.

results.headline: Adult Responsibilities, but a Child’s Sensibility

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Boy

results.summary_short: “Boy,” an unpretentious comic tale of a youngster’s growing relationship with a long-absent father, has a surprising rhythmic genius.

results.headline: Collecting Emotion, and Not in Tranquillity

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Black Butterflies

results.summary_short: Paula Van der Oest’s film “Black Butterflies” is a biopic about the poet Ingrid Jonker, who has been called the Sylvia Plath of South Africa.

results.headline: Welcome to Uganda. Please Look Around.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Where Are You Taking Me?

results.summary_short: Kimi Takesue’s “Where Are You Taking Me,” is a tour of Uganda that is not quite a travelogue and not quite an art show.

results.headline: Back to Nature With Wii and Cheez-Its

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Woods

results.summary_short: “The Woods,” envisions a utopian society in the Pacific Northwest where the Wi-Fi is as close as the nearest tree, until it’s destroyed by catastrophe.

results.headline: A Father and Son Reunion on the Way to the Abyss

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Being Flynn

results.summary_short: In “Being Flynn,” directed by Paul Weitz, Robert De Niro reminds us of how resourceful an actor he can be.

results.headline: A Robin Hood in a Chinese Western

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Let the Bullets Fly

results.summary_short: “Let the Bullets Fly” is a noodle western that follows the exploits of a train robber turned good guy (apparently).

results.headline: Getting Bobby to Come Out and Play

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Last Days Here

results.summary_short: “Last Days Here” documents the drug-fueled descent and attempted resuscitation of the Pentagram frontman Bobby Liebling.

results.headline: A Rebel’s Tale

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paan Singh Tomar

results.summary_short: Irrfan Khan, whose performance in HBO’s “In Treatment” won acclaim, plays a champion runner turned bandit in Tigmanshu Dhulia’s film “Paan Singh Tomar.”

results.headline: How the Grinch Stole the Lorax

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dr. Seuss' The Lorax

results.summary_short: “Dr. Seuss’ The Lorax,” the movie version of the children’s book, is a noisy, useless piece of junk, reverse-engineered into something resembling popular art.

results.headline: Looking Ahead to Dying Young

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Better Than Something: Jay Reatard

results.summary_short: With candid interviews and raw performance footage, “Better Than Something” traces the volatile, short life of the garage rocker known as Jay Reatard.

results.headline: Examining Romanian Fault Lines

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Niki and Flo

results.summary_short: In “Niki and Flo,” two aging neighbors linked by the marriage of their children represent a bridge — and also a battle — between the old Romania and the new.

results.headline: A Video From Tehran: It’s Not What It Isn’t, but What It Is

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of This Is Not A Film

results.summary_short: Jafar Panahi, one of the leading Iranian filmmakers who has been banned from making movies, sits before a camera in “This Is Not a Film.”

results.headline: Rich Guy, Poor Girl: It Could Never Work

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tyler Perry's Good Deeds

results.summary_short: “Tyler Perry’s Good Deeds” honors goodness in an oh-so-serious fairy tale about a homeless janitor and her wealthy savior.
